items.text: Javac annotation processor uses rounds instead of defining processors order.
items.href: java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow

items.text: So normally the simplified algorithm is like that:
items.href: java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow
java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow
java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow

items.text: Any annotation processor can generate new files using Filer.
items.href: java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow

items.text: Gather all generated files and if there are any, run step 2 again.
items.href: java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow

items.text: If there are no files generated, run one more round where RoundEnvironment.processingOver() returns true, signaling this is the last round.
items.href: java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow

items.text: Note: javac still uses multiple rounds, it just can't pick up generated kotlin sources.
items.href: java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow

items.text: One possible option is to move your generated classes into a separate module like it's described here.
items.href: java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow

items.text: But the easiest option is to generate java code directly and your generated java classes will be picked up by javac automatically, launching second round of annotation processing, where dagger will process them.
items.href: java - Dagger can not find classes generated by other annotation processor - Stack Overflow
